WHEELING IN EUROPE.

In writing a few hints on the subject of summer touring awheel in Europe, I am aware
that advice on matters pertaining to wheeling
must necessarily be somewhat relative in character. It is hard to lay down fixed rules on
this subject. I therefore propose to give
merely a few general hints, and to state some
of my personal experiences in this line of sport.
First, then, as to the bicycle itself. It is not
WO much trouble to take one's own wheel to
Europe. The freight across the Atlantic
amounts only to two or three dollars, and, if
the wheel be well packed in a wooden box, it
will not suffer on the journey. Bicycles can
be landed in England free of charge, but on
the continent this is not the case. It is, therefore, advisable for tourists intending to cycle
on the continent to join the "Cyclist's Touring
Club," of England, or the "Touring Club," of
France. To do this, it is necessary only to
send the dues to the secretary of either club,
together with the names of two indorsers who
are already members. The C. T. C. is now
just as useful on the continent as the C. T. F.,
and members of the English Club are permitted to take their wheels to the continent without making the usual deposit of ten or twelve
dollars.
With regard to the gear of the wheel, my experience has been that for all round touring,
which is liable to embrace the mountains of
Switzerland and Italy, as well as the hills of
England and Scotland, the gear should not
exceed seventy to seventy-three inches.
I am a great advocate of the double tire—
the Dunlop or any .other good make. Of
course, partisans of the single tube are to be
found, but apart from the fact that these tires
are little used in Europe (and therefore could
not be so easily repaired en route in case of a
serious break), there can be no denying the

No. 15

fact that, even if the double tire requires
slightly more labor to mend, the repair once
made is more permanent. On the sharp flints
which are found on French roads it is not unusual to puncture one's tire two or three times
in one afternoon, and a single tube with five
or six repairs in it becomes, to say the least,
somewhat "porous." Beware, intending tourist, of using wooden rims with a clincher-tire
of the type of the Dunlop. For this experiment I once paid with half an hour of unconsciousness, which came upon me without
warning in the middle of a delightful "coast"
in the Shenandoah valley. Let the aspirant
to the twenty-mile "coasts" of the Alps be
warned, also, against riding without a brake,
or using a brake which is in any way inefficient. For this slight lapse from the path of
perfect prudence I was once rewarded by an
instantaneous leap from my wheel on the brink
of the Ticino, on the St. Gothard, and by the
deplorable sight of a mangled front fork. My
experience, it will be seen, has been hardearned, and the reader should at least regard
my advice as sincere.
By all means, ride with a gear case. I have
ridden with one from London to Edinburgh
and back without once cleaning my chain, and
oiling it only once. In London a gear case
can be bought and fitted over the chain for five
or six dollars.
Mud-guards may be dispensed with, and the
use of a lamp may be obviated by arranging
one's schedule so as to reach one's destination
daily at a certain time. In Italy, however, the
regulations about lamps are somewhat severe.
There remains the question of baggage, by
no means a simple matter. The best bag to
carry is one which is placed in front of the
wheel (not over the handle-bar), and which is
fastened by two straps to the handle-bar, and
by a third strap to the front bar of the frame,

"Special attention will be given that branch
of astronomy and physics called astrophysics,
which is concerned with the application of
spectrum analysis to the heavenly bodies. Since
the invention of the concave grating by Prof.
Rowland, all the laboratories in the world have
been gradually acquiring grating-spectroscopes; but, naturally, no laboratory is so well
equipped as ours. In May, 19oo, there will be
a solar eclipse, which will be visible in Virginia near Norfolk, and at that time there will
be many astronomers from America and
abroad who will be coming to Baltimore on
their way to observe the eclipse. It is our intention to arrange for several courses of lectures given by various distinguished professors and observers from a distance.
"In the field of engineering, especial attention will be given the needs of advanced students. The purpose in this is to offer to electrical engineers and others those facilities in the
way of lectures and laboratory work which are
not available elsewhere in this country. There
are many institutions throughout the land
where undergraduate students may obtain instruction preparatory to the work of an electrical engineer; but there is no institution which
directs the attention solely to the needs of engineers and advanced students.
"Among the new courses will be lectures on
the subject of terrestrial magnetism, on geological physics, and one on the methods and
observations of meteorology. The facilities
of the University in these lines of investigation
are unequaled, owing to the connection of the
Government Weather Bureau and the State
Geological Survey with the University."
These improvements and additions of
equipment will be more apparent when the

further action. It is known, however, that
the resignation of Professor Duncan has been

THE '99 HULLABALOO.

The main features of the annual "Hullabaldo" have now become so firmly fixed by
tradition, that successive editorial boards find
any great departure from the norm unwise.
Variety must be attained by attention to details. The '99 "Hullabaloo," which is now in
press, follows the general rule in this regard.
The cover is in cloth and paper, with simple
lettering and new color effects. A new shade
of red is the important feature. The title page
is an exquisite water-color design reproduced
by the three-color process. This is an entirely
new departure in Hopkins annuals, and promises to be one of the most attractive features
of this year's book.
The leading article is written by President
Gilman, under the title, "Early Days at Johns
Hopkins." It includes many interesting reminiscences of the founding of the University
and anecdotes about men connected with its
early development. An excellent steel engraving of President Gilman serves as frontispiece. This is the first time that such a process has been used, and this year's "Hullabaloo" is the first book for a number of years
to contain a portrait of the President.
Throughout the book, special attention has
been paid to illustrations. The title drawings
will be found of unusual merit. The senior
class is presented in detail with a half-tone portrait of each member. The usual athletic organizations and miscellaneous clubs are well
represented. Care has been taken to omit unnecessary statistics and long articles. The
literary articles are short and interesting. A
few more or less prominent individuals are the
subjects of mild satire. The military enthusiasm of last year is not forgotten. A spirited
mock-heroic relates the events that centered
about the junior banquet of last year.
The number of pages is reduced, relieving
the book of unnecessary bulkiness, and a new
shape has been adopted. For the first time
the staff have acted as their own publishers,
and the venture promises to be a financial success. The first consignment of books will be
received from the printer some time during
the first week in May.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
nusicAL CLUBS' ELECTIONS.
The recent elections of the Glee, Banjo and
Mandolin Clubs have decided the officers and
leaders of the organization for the year of
I899-19oo. E. Skipwith Bruce, who has acted
as assistant manager during the last year, was
elected president, while John H. King, under
whose successful management the clubs have
paid off a two-year old debt of over two hundred dollars, will continue to represent the
business end, with Wilson L. Smith as assistant manager. Charles A. Vogeler and Walter
Krager will lead the Mandolin and Banjo
Clubs respectively. Both have had extensive
club experience. Vogeler has played on the
Lawrenceville and Johns Hopkins Clubs, while
Krager has played for several years on both
the Banjo and Mandolin Clubs of the University. Stephen Harwood will add to his ancient role of "star song bird," the leadership of
the Glee Club. The officers and leaders of the
various clubs promise to fulfill their parts well,
and there is every reason to hope for good
clubs next year. The pleasure to be derived
from membership is well known, and an excellent chance will be offered next year for new
men to get places. The summer vacation will
afford an excellent opportunity for learning to
play a banjo or mandolin, and thus securing
one of the vacancies that will occur next
season.
The gay brilliance of the basement has gone;
the Medical and Chirurgical Faculty has left
us, but long after their departure the corridors
of McCoy Hall have been decked with portraits of some of the most distinguished physicians that the Faculty has numbered among
its members—men who have gained honor for
themselves and Maryland in their profession.
Considering the high place the Johns Hopkins
Medical School holds, it was fitting that this
important celebration of the moth anniversary of the Medical Faculty should be held at
the University. The meetings were under the
direction of Dr. S. C. Chew, President of the
Faculty. A number of instructive papers were
read and addresses made on the theory and

5

history of medicine by prominent physicians
and surgeons.

CRESCENTS, 5 ; HOPKINS, 2.
On the, 29th our lacrosse team lined up
against the famous Crescent Athletic Club, the
champions of this country for the past five or
six years. Although our team suffered defeat, it played a magnificent game, holding the
score down to 5 to 2, the same score by which
the Crescents beat Toronto University, the
champions of Canada, last year. Unfortunately both Abercrombie and Fitzgerald were
hurt early in the game by the needlessly rough
playing of the Crescents, thus weakening our
team. The score at the end of the first half
was 2 to 1. McInnes, Maddren and Guggenheimer so distinguished themselves that they
were asked to play for the champions this
summer. "Billy "Hodges,a member of our '98
team, played third attack for the visitors, and
was a conspicuous thorn in our side. As the
Crescents said, it was a fine, close-fought
game, and showed once again what true fighting blood our boys have.
In compliance with the desires of influential
members of the Athletic Association, the trustees have lately decided to designate a new
"Committee on Athletics and Gymnastics,"
two members of which represent the faculty,
three the recent alumni, and two the resident
students. The members of the committee
representing the authorities are Prof. Renouf,
who has been for many years deeply interested
in Hopkins athletics, and Prof. Reid, who was
distinguished as a gymnast in his undergraduate days, and was one of the earliest advocates of a new gymnasium. The alumni members, as both students and as alumni, have
maintained a warm interest in the University's
athletic welfare. They are: Allan McLane,
A. B., 1886; James Shaler Hodges, A. B.,
1886; George C. Morrison, A. B., 189o. The
students on the committee are W. H. Maddren, of the Medical School and lacrosse team,

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

and R. H. Grimes, of the class of '99 and also
of the lacrosse team.
This committee has selected Mr. William
W. Mackdermott as Instructor in Athletics
and Gymnastics, and their nomination has
been confirmed by the trustees.

HOPKINS, 12,; STEVENS, I.
Stevens came down from the Dutch precincts of Hoboken with the earnest and fixed
intention of cleaning things up hereabouts.
Upon close inspection we must admit that they
succeeded, only, unfortunately for Stevens,
they put the cart before the horse. Poor Stevens certainly traveled a thorny road; confident of victory, and determined to avenge their
8 to i defeat of last year, they fell Saturday
twelve various times. Upon the whole, we
cannot wonder that MacDonald, the Stevens
captain, wanted to know where we got such a
team; nor at his astonishment upon being informed that it was the work of an American
amateur coach, our great star player, Maddren. The game started off with a rush, Stevens tallying the first goal after thiry-five seconds of play, by fast, perfect tipping, catching and running. That woke up our attack,
and for the next ten minutes they kept pegging away at the Stevens goal, only to be
thwarted again and again by the really miraculous work of the Stevens goal-keeper, Layatt. Suddenly Abercrombie gets the ball, tips
it to "Fitz," who sends it to McInnes; bang it
goes to Grimes, and swat! it is in the goal net.
The score is tied. During the rest of the half
the J. H. U. attack chased the ball around the
lot to the tune of six more goals. The chief
irouble at the beginning was the combination
of Stevens' brilliant playing and the nervousness of our attack.
The second half was even more savagely
fought, for Stevens became desperate, but,
even playing probably better than they ever
did before, they could not stop our scoring,
nor score against the best lacrosse team that
ever represented an American college.

As for the individual playing, it is hard to
particularize when every man is a star. Abercrombie, our "Aber," was everywhere and
anywhere, now playing on the defense, now
carrying the ball down to the attack, now
shooting at goal. He played a truly wonderful game, and showed his great fund of endurance and skill. Grimes, Fitzgerald, McInnes,
Bandel and Sayler all did heroically, and if
space permitted would be individually complimented. The playing of the defense field,
Foster, Bruton and Tyler, was a revelation to
those who realized that it was a green defense.
Foster, especially, did great work. Both Maddren and "Guggy" did even better than their
best, and electrified the crowd again and again
with their brilliant playing. Griffin also
showed out to advantage, with his telling running and his body-checking. In fact, the
whole team was one large constellation.

TFIE TRACK TEAM

In the annual spring games held last Saturday by Georgetown University, at Washington, our track and field team continued to win
honors. After several weeks of steady training under Father Mack, the boys were in fine
form.
In the number of points scored we stood
next to Georgetown herself, and if Garrett had
been entered also we might have stood about
equal. Mullen did some pretty work against
the Georgetown cracks ill the quarter-mile,
winning fourth place against all the stars, such
as Mulligan and others. Scholl jumped five
feet nine inches, tying for first place in the
high jump and winning the broad. The fact
that he lost on the toss of a coin does not detract from the merit of his work. In the halfmile, Riggs, our star half-back of last fall, ran
a beautiful race, winning second place against
some of Georgetown's best runners.
Clark did some steady running, and made a
third place. Knapp was third in the 220-yard
dash, and third in the mo-yard finals.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
To every Hopkins man who witnessed the
University of Pennsylvania relay races, on
Franklin Field, on Saturday, May 29, there
came a thrill of pleasure when he saw Mullen trotting in ahead of Armstrong, the University of Maryland sprinter. To be sure,
there were but two competitors in the class,
Maryland and Hopkins, since Columbian University, of Washington, and St. John's College, failed to appear, but there was a certain
extreme delight in beating Maryland. It is
said that the faculty of Columbian disapproved
of the endeavors that were made to secure athletic material, and for that reason summarily
"shut down" on the track team, and refused
them permission to enter.
- Clark, Riggs, Captain Knapp and Mullen
ran in the order named, and each beat his man
out. From the time Clark started to gain on
McPhail, the Hopkins boys were never
headed, and it was merely a question of what
Captain
our lead would be at the finish.
Knapp ran in beautiful form, and considerably
increased the size of the gap between Miller
and himself. Mullen ran the last quarter, and
assured our sprinters of their gold watches
and banner. The latter has been added to the
number which already adorn the north wall of
the common room. George Radcliffe, who
was a regular member of the victorious team
last year, was the only substitute. Coachelect Mackdermott accompanied the team to
Philadelphia, where they went on the Friday
before the games, and put up at the Colonnade Hotel, where Cornell and other of the
teams were domiciled.
Riggs, who did such creditable work on the
'Varsity football team last season, as well as
in-the B. A. C. games at the rink, and Clark,
the two new members of the relay team, ran
well, and more than held their own with the
Maryland runners. The record of 3.43 1-5,
made last year by Hopkins, was reduced onefifth of a second.
As the Black and Blue has now won in her
class two years in succession, it is believed that
next year she will be placed in a higher class,
possibly with Georgetown.

7
BASEBALL.

• We are looking forward now with great
expectancy to the intercollegiate baseball
championship'of the State. By our victory
over Western Maryland, on Saturday, we neutralized the bad effects of our defeat by Gallaudet on the preceding Saturday, and stand
just as we formerly did—at the top of the list.
Gallaudet lost to Washington College by a
score of 3 to 5, and our victory thus places us
even with the mutes for first place. We have
already badly defeated Washington College,
the only team which was to be feared, and the
Agriculturals should be easy now.
Of the three games which have been played
since our last issue, two have been defeats,
and one, a victory. The game with Gallaudet
should have been won easily, and there is
really no excuse for losing it. Stage fright
did it. When the score was 6 to i in our
favor, to go to work and make enough errors
to let the other side beat us out was pretty bad
work. Perhaps we shouldn't criticise the
team for nervousness which can't be helped,
but, what on earth was there to be afraid of?
We are really much stronger than they are, and
if we get another chance we'll prove it.
We expected Georgetown to wipe up the
floor with us—and she did it. Georgetown
has won an uninterrupted string of victories
this spring, and of course we couldn't do anything at all with her. But we might have
made at least one run.
We could not bat, that was the main trouble. Wight, Joyner and Clarke, the heavy
hitters, simply fanned at Bach's and Kenna's
curves, and only one man got to third base.
Strouse was ailing, too. He had to pitch .
while he was not feeling well, and poor support soon rattled him. The score, 15 to o, tells
the tale.
At Westminster, Strouse was on hand with
a fine assortment of new and original strikeouts, and succeeded in imposing eleven of
them upon the collegians. He had perfect
support, too, the infield and outfield vying in
the good work. The batting was also up to
the standard. The whole team put up a fine
game.

8

THE NEWS-LETTER.

A little more of this kind of work and we
shall have the pennant. Then Captain Joyner
and Jimmy Swaine, and the others who persevered early in the season, will be able to feel
that they have the approval and admiration of
all their fellow-students.
"MINER PHYSICS."
Ez I wuz shuvin' boxes 'round t'earn me daily
bread,
'N me pulse wuz beatin' weary, 'n me arms
wuz gittin' dead,
I happened, lookin' t'rough a door, upon er
funny sight,
I hollors t' de janiter, 'n squints wid all me
might.
"Wot makes de succers sweat so hard, wot
makes 'em squirm 'n shrink?" '
"Dey're bein' quizzed," responds me pard, "'n
dey're tryin' t' t'ink,
Wi(l splutt'ring questions in der ears 'n mem'ry growin' low,
W'ile Am-s is learnin' acc'rately de t'ings det
dey dunno."
Per he's quizzin' "Miner Physics," he is quizzin' em t'day,
He's tramplin' on der feelinks in a bloomin'
brutal way,
He's loadin"em wid zeros w'ich he's stickin'
on ter stay,
'N he's quizzin' "Miner Physics" in der morr-nin'.
"Wot kind er cove is Am—s?" asks I, wid curiosity;
"He is an enenint Physacist—a queer monstrosity;
Writin"laws uv nature' on er board in rigid
calculations,
Ez if Gawd, t' make de universe, used Algebra
equations."
"W'y are some holdin' up der paws, 'n most
are lookin' pale?"
"He's asked who's studied 'nature's laws'—de
paws dey tells de tale.
So dey're between de devil 'n a very deep blue
sea."
I asks, "W'ich is de devil?" "I leave det t'
you," sez he.

Per he's quizzin' "Miner Physics," he is quizzin' em t'day,
Dey're wigglin"n dey're wormin', but dey kinnot git away;
De blood is zoonin' in der heads, de numbers
growin' gray,
'N he's quizzin' "Miner Physics" in de morr-nin'.
'N wid det, I wint t' wur-rk wid a lighter
heart, t'inking det it wuz more fun shuvin' a
box around den findin' its inertia.
ORLANDO MCGINNIS, A. J., Ph. D.,
Assistant Janitor, Physics Department).

By the withdrawal of Johns Hopkins from
the Maryland Athletic Union, we perhaps lose
a chance of adding to our number of cups and
banners at the games in June. Last September we carried off everything in sight.
The point which Messrs. McInnes and Ballard raised was just. An athlete cannot remain in perfect trim so long between the preliminaries and the finals as to do himself justice. It's a pity, though, that we have to lose
such a chance as this.

resolutions were passed expressing regret at

WHEELING IN EUROPE.

In writing a few hints on the subject of summer touring awheel in Europe, I am aware
that advice on matters pertaining to wheeling
must necessarily be somewhat relative in character. It is hard to lay down fixed rules on
this subject. I therefore propose to give
merely a few general hints, and to state some
of my personal experiences in this line of sport.
First, then, as to the bicycle itself. It is not
WO much trouble to take one's own wheel to
Europe. The freight across the Atlantic
amounts only to two or three dollars, and, if
the wheel be well packed in a wooden box, it
will not suffer on the journey. Bicycles can
be landed in England free of charge, but on
the continent this is not the case. It is, therefore, advisable for tourists intending to cycle
on the continent to join the "Cyclist's Touring
Club," of England, or the "Touring Club," of
France. To do this, it is necessary only to
send the dues to the secretary of either club,
together with the names of two indorsers who
are already members. The C. T. C. is now
just as useful on the continent as the C. T. F.,
and members of the English Club are permitted to take their wheels to the continent without making the usual deposit of ten or twelve
dollars.
With regard to the gear of the wheel, my experience has been that for all round touring,
which is liable to embrace the mountains of
Switzerland and Italy, as well as the hills of
England and Scotland, the gear should not
exceed seventy to seventy-three inches.
I am a great advocate of the double tire—
the Dunlop or any .other good make. Of
course, partisans of the single tube are to be
found, but apart from the fact that these tires
are little used in Europe (and therefore could
not be so easily repaired en route in case of a
serious break), there can be no denying the

No. 15

fact that, even if the double tire requires
slightly more labor to mend, the repair once
made is more permanent. On the sharp flints
which are found on French roads it is not unusual to puncture one's tire two or three times
in one afternoon, and a single tube with five
or six repairs in it becomes, to say the least,
somewhat "porous." Beware, intending tourist, of using wooden rims with a clincher-tire
of the type of the Dunlop. For this experiment I once paid with half an hour of unconsciousness, which came upon me without
warning in the middle of a delightful "coast"
in the Shenandoah valley. Let the aspirant
to the twenty-mile "coasts" of the Alps be
warned, also, against riding without a brake,
or using a brake which is in any way inefficient. For this slight lapse from the path of
perfect prudence I was once rewarded by an
instantaneous leap from my wheel on the brink
of the Ticino, on the St. Gothard, and by the
deplorable sight of a mangled front fork. My

"Special attention will be given that branch
of astronomy and physics called astrophysics,
which is concerned with the application of
spectrum analysis to the heavenly bodies. Since
the invention of the concave grating by Prof.
Rowland, all the laboratories in the world have
been gradually acquiring grating-spectroscopes; but, naturally, no laboratory is so well
equipped as ours. In May, 19oo, there will be
a solar eclipse, which will be visible in Virginia near Norfolk, and at that time there will
be many astronomers from America and
abroad who will be coming to Baltimore on
their way to observe the eclipse. It is our intention to arrange for several courses of lectures given by various distinguished professors and observers from a distance.
"In the field of engineering, especial attention will be given the needs of advanced students. The purpose in this is to offer to electrical engineers and others those facilities in the
way of lectures and laboratory work which are
not available elsewhere in this country. There
are many institutions throughout the land
where undergraduate students may obtain instruction preparatory to the work of an electrical engineer; but there is no institution which
directs the attention solely to the needs of engineers and advanced students.

the subject of terrestrial magnetism, on geological physics, and one on the methods and
observations of meteorology. The facilities
of the University in these lines of investigation
are unequaled, owing to the connection of the
Government Weather Bureau and the State

THE '99 HULLABALOO.

The main features of the annual "Hullabaldo" have now become so firmly fixed by
tradition, that successive editorial boards find
any great departure from the norm unwise.
Variety must be attained by attention to details. The '99 "Hullabaloo," which is now in
press, follows the general rule in this regard.
The cover is in cloth and paper, with simple
lettering and new color effects. A new shade
of red is the important feature. The title page
is an exquisite water-color design reproduced
by the three-color process. This is an entirely
new departure in Hopkins annuals, and promises to be one of the most attractive features
of this year's book.
The leading article is written by President
Gilman, under the title, "Early Days at Johns
Hopkins." It includes many interesting reminiscences of the founding of the University
and anecdotes about men connected with its
early development. An excellent steel engraving of President Gilman serves as frontispiece. This is the first time that such a process has been used, and this year's "Hullabaloo" is the first book for a number of years
to contain a portrait of the President.
Throughout the book, special attention has
been paid to illustrations. The title drawings
will be found of unusual merit. The senior
class is presented in detail with a half-tone portrait of each member. The usual athletic organizations and miscellaneous clubs are well
represented. Care has been taken to omit unnecessary statistics and long articles. The
literary articles are short and interesting. A
few more or less prominent individuals are the
subjects of mild satire. The military enthusiasm of last year is not forgotten. A spirited
mock-heroic relates the events that centered
about the junior banquet of last year.
The number of pages is reduced, relieving
the book of unnecessary bulkiness, and a new
shape has been adopted. For the first time
the staff have acted as their own publishers,
and the venture promises to be a financial success. The first consignment of books will be
received from the printer some time during
the first week in May.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
nusicAL CLUBS' ELECTIONS.
The recent elections of the Glee, Banjo and
Mandolin Clubs have decided the officers and
leaders of the organization for the year of
I899-19oo. E. Skipwith Bruce, who has acted
as assistant manager during the last year, was
elected president, while John H. King, under
whose successful management the clubs have
paid off a two-year old debt of over two hundred dollars, will continue to represent the
business end, with Wilson L. Smith as assistant manager. Charles A. Vogeler and Walter
Krager will lead the Mandolin and Banjo
Clubs respectively. Both have had extensive
club experience. Vogeler has played on the
Lawrenceville and Johns Hopkins Clubs, while
Krager has played for several years on both
the Banjo and Mandolin Clubs of the University. Stephen Harwood will add to his ancient role of "star song bird," the leadership of
the Glee Club. The officers and leaders of the
various clubs promise to fulfill their parts well,
and there is every reason to hope for good
clubs next year. The pleasure to be derived
from membership is well known, and an excellent chance will be offered next year for new
men to get places. The summer vacation will
afford an excellent opportunity for learning to
play a banjo or mandolin, and thus securing
one of the vacancies that will occur next
season.
The gay brilliance of the basement has gone;
the Medical and Chirurgical Faculty has left
us, but long after their departure the corridors
of McCoy Hall have been decked with portraits of some of the most distinguished physicians that the Faculty has numbered among
its members—men who have gained honor for
themselves and Maryland in their profession.
Considering the high place the Johns Hopkins
Medical School holds, it was fitting that this
important celebration of the moth anniversary of the Medical Faculty should be held at
the University. The meetings were under the
direction of Dr. S. C. Chew, President of the
Faculty. A number of instructive papers were
read and addresses made on the theory and

5

history of medicine by prominent physicians
and surgeons.

CRESCENTS, 5 ; HOPKINS, 2.
On the, 29th our lacrosse team lined up
against the famous Crescent Athletic Club, the
champions of this country for the past five or
six years. Although our team suffered defeat, it played a magnificent game, holding the
score down to 5 to 2, the same score by which
the Crescents beat Toronto University, the
champions of Canada, last year. Unfortunately both Abercrombie and Fitzgerald were
hurt early in the game by the needlessly rough
playing of the Crescents, thus weakening our
team. The score at the end of the first half
was 2 to 1. McInnes, Maddren and Guggenheimer so distinguished themselves that they
were asked to play for the champions this
summer. "Billy "Hodges,a member of our '98
team, played third attack for the visitors, and
was a conspicuous thorn in our side. As the
Crescents said, it was a fine, close-fought
game, and showed once again what true fighting blood our boys have.
In compliance with the desires of influential
members of the Athletic Association, the trustees have lately decided to designate a new
"Committee on Athletics and Gymnastics,"
two members of which represent the faculty,
three the recent alumni, and two the resident
students. The members of the committee
representing the authorities are Prof. Renouf,
who has been for many years deeply interested
in Hopkins athletics, and Prof. Reid, who was
distinguished as a gymnast in his undergraduate days, and was one of the earliest advocates of a new gymnasium. The alumni members, as both students and as alumni, have
maintained a warm interest in the University's
athletic welfare. They are: Allan McLane,
A. B., 1886; James Shaler Hodges, A. B.,
1886; George C. Morrison, A. B., 189o. The
students on the committee are W. H. Maddren, of the Medical School and lacrosse team,

6

THE NEWS-LETTER.

and R. H. Grimes, of the class of '99 and also
of the lacrosse team.
This committee has selected Mr. William
W. Mackdermott as Instructor in Athletics
and Gymnastics, and their nomination has
been confirmed by the trustees.

HOPKINS, 12,; STEVENS, I.
Stevens came down from the Dutch precincts of Hoboken with the earnest and fixed
intention of cleaning things up hereabouts.
Upon close inspection we must admit that they
succeeded, only, unfortunately for Stevens,
they put the cart before the horse. Poor Stevens certainly traveled a thorny road; confident of victory, and determined to avenge their
8 to i defeat of last year, they fell Saturday
twelve various times. Upon the whole, we
cannot wonder that MacDonald, the Stevens
captain, wanted to know where we got such a
team; nor at his astonishment upon being informed that it was the work of an American
amateur coach, our great star player, Maddren. The game started off with a rush, Stevens tallying the first goal after thiry-five seconds of play, by fast, perfect tipping, catching and running. That woke up our attack,
and for the next ten minutes they kept pegging away at the Stevens goal, only to be
thwarted again and again by the really miraculous work of the Stevens goal-keeper, Layatt. Suddenly Abercrombie gets the ball, tips
it to "Fitz," who sends it to McInnes; bang it
goes to Grimes, and swat! it is in the goal net.
The score is tied. During the rest of the half
the J. H. U. attack chased the ball around the
lot to the tune of six more goals. The chief
irouble at the beginning was the combination
of Stevens' brilliant playing and the nervousness of our attack.
The second half was even more savagely
fought, for Stevens became desperate, but,
even playing probably better than they ever
did before, they could not stop our scoring,
nor score against the best lacrosse team that
ever represented an American college.

As for the individual playing, it is hard to
particularize when every man is a star. Abercrombie, our "Aber," was everywhere and
anywhere, now playing on the defense, now
carrying the ball down to the attack, now
shooting at goal. He played a truly wonderful game, and showed his great fund of endurance and skill. Grimes, Fitzgerald, McInnes,
Bandel and Sayler all did heroically, and if
space permitted would be individually complimented. The playing of the defense field,
Foster, Bruton and Tyler, was a revelation to
those who realized that it was a green defense.
Foster, especially, did great work. Both Maddren and "Guggy" did even better than their
best, and electrified the crowd again and again
with their brilliant playing. Griffin also
showed out to advantage, with his telling running and his body-checking. In fact, the
whole team was one large constellation.

TFIE TRACK TEAM

In the annual spring games held last Saturday by Georgetown University, at Washington, our track and field team continued to win
honors. After several weeks of steady training under Father Mack, the boys were in fine
form.
In the number of points scored we stood
next to Georgetown herself, and if Garrett had
been entered also we might have stood about
equal. Mullen did some pretty work against
the Georgetown cracks ill the quarter-mile,
winning fourth place against all the stars, such
as Mulligan and others. Scholl jumped five
feet nine inches, tying for first place in the
high jump and winning the broad. The fact
that he lost on the toss of a coin does not detract from the merit of his work. In the halfmile, Riggs, our star half-back of last fall, ran
a beautiful race, winning second place against
some of Georgetown's best runners.
Clark did some steady running, and made a
third place. Knapp was third in the 220-yard
dash, and third in the mo-yard finals.

THE NEWS-LETTER.
To every Hopkins man who witnessed the
University of Pennsylvania relay races, on
Franklin Field, on Saturday, May 29, there
came a thrill of pleasure when he saw Mullen trotting in ahead of Armstrong, the University of Maryland sprinter. To be sure,
there were but two competitors in the class,
Maryland and Hopkins, since Columbian University, of Washington, and St. John's College, failed to appear, but there was a certain
extreme delight in beating Maryland. It is
said that the faculty of Columbian disapproved
of the endeavors that were made to secure athletic material, and for that reason summarily
"shut down" on the track team, and refused
them permission to enter.
- Clark, Riggs, Captain Knapp and Mullen
ran in the order named, and each beat his man
out. From the time Clark started to gain on
McPhail, the Hopkins boys were never
headed, and it was merely a question of what
Captain
our lead would be at the finish.
Knapp ran in beautiful form, and considerably
increased the size of the gap between Miller
and himself. Mullen ran the last quarter, and
assured our sprinters of their gold watches
and banner. The latter has been added to the
number which already adorn the north wall of
the common room. George Radcliffe, who
was a regular member of the victorious team
last year, was the only substitute. Coachelect Mackdermott accompanied the team to
Philadelphia, where they went on the Friday
before the games, and put up at the Colonnade Hotel, where Cornell and other of the
teams were domiciled.
Riggs, who did such creditable work on the
'Varsity football team last season, as well as
in-the B. A. C. games at the rink, and Clark,
the two new members of the relay team, ran
well, and more than held their own with the
Maryland runners. The record of 3.43 1-5,
made last year by Hopkins, was reduced onefifth of a second.
As the Black and Blue has now won in her
class two years in succession, it is believed that
next year she will be placed in a higher class,
possibly with Georgetown.

BASEBALL.

• We are looking forward now with great
expectancy to the intercollegiate baseball
championship'of the State. By our victory
over Western Maryland, on Saturday, we neutralized the bad effects of our defeat by Gallaudet on the preceding Saturday, and stand
just as we formerly did—at the top of the list.
Gallaudet lost to Washington College by a
score of 3 to 5, and our victory thus places us
even with the mutes for first place. We have
already badly defeated Washington College,
the only team which was to be feared, and the
Agriculturals should be easy now.
Of the three games which have been played
since our last issue, two have been defeats,
and one, a victory. The game with Gallaudet
should have been won easily, and there is
really no excuse for losing it. Stage fright
did it. When the score was 6 to i in our
favor, to go to work and make enough errors
to let the other side beat us out was pretty bad
work. Perhaps we shouldn't criticise the
team for nervousness which can't be helped,
but, what on earth was there to be afraid of?
We are really much stronger than they are, and
if we get another chance we'll prove it.
We expected Georgetown to wipe up the
floor with us—and she did it. Georgetown
has won an uninterrupted string of victories
this spring, and of course we couldn't do anything at all with her. But we might have
made at least one run.
We could not bat, that was the main trouble. Wight, Joyner and Clarke, the heavy
hitters, simply fanned at Bach's and Kenna's
curves, and only one man got to third base.
Strouse was ailing, too. He had to pitch .
while he was not feeling well, and poor support soon rattled him. The score, 15 to o, tells
the tale.
At Westminster, Strouse was on hand with
a fine assortment of new and original strikeouts, and succeeded in imposing eleven of
them upon the collegians. He had perfect
support, too, the infield and outfield vying in
the good work. The batting was also up to
the standard. The whole team put up a fine
game.

"W'y are some holdin' up der paws, 'n most

• Sometimes we are asked,"Why do not the other stores
show as many styles and as good Clothing as you do?"
This is a question that we cannot answer. There is no
patent on making good Clothing, and there is no reason
